text: I'm sure you've been asked before, and I probably know the answers to them myself, but maybe a lot of the listeners in the radio show won't. So, you know, just put up with that, I guess. Oh, sure, yeah. I'm well used to that. Yeah, I'm sure. Tell me your front name again. Darryl. Darryl. Yeah, Darryl. Okay. I'm an English teacher here at Odessa College. Right. Okay, listen, you obviously had an extremely varied background, and I wondered if you could just say a few words about how you began as a writer. Okay. I began to write when I was an able seaman in the Merchant Marine, and how that came about was that I left home before I graduated from high school. It's a fascinating thing. I lecture at colleges and universities all over the United States and in England and in France, And I have yet to get my high school diploma. Someday somebody will grant me an honorary high school diploma. But anyway, I was on the ship. And you had a lot of time to read. And I conceived the idea of an absolutely foolproof crime that would net me thousands and thousands of dollars. And I even did research on it. I was on a coastwise tanker. And as I was going up and down the coast, when we stopped at a port, I would send off a letter to the railroad, so it was one of the things that was involved, and the insurance companies, that was another, and the post office, that was still another. I got all my research done as to how to commit this particular kind of robbery, and they had letters carefully written so that nobody would know what I was up to. And when I had all my material, I found that I did not have the immoral courage to commit the crime, so I wrote it as a story. this was way back in the late 30s and i sent my story off to a newspaper syndicate i didn't know anything about writing particularly and there was they were buying a 1500 word short short stories that they published every day in the in the syndicate and uh when i got up to new york in the ship to my amazement i got a letter of acceptance and uh so i quit the sea and and came ashore to be a writer. And I got my money, not on acceptance, but on publication. And it was five whole dollars. And they would buy one and sometimes two stories a week, but no more. And so four and a half months or so, I lived on five and sometimes ten dollars a week. My room cost me seven. And whatever I saved, I could eat. And I learned a lot about being hungry. Did you ever notice that pound cake has no crust on the ends? What they do is chop them off and they sell them in their day-old store. And at that time, you could get a whole shopping bag full of cake ends for a nickel. And so I used to live on that. One time, I got a whole shopping bag full and it was moldy, but I ate it anyhow. And I was so sick, I didn't eat for three days, and so I saved myself some money. You know, like that. It was a hard school. it really was but then I finally after some months of that and I think I went back to C for a short while I finally met John Campbell in 1939 early 1939 he was the editor of Astounding Science Fiction and a wonderful fantasy magazine called Unknown and so I started writing for him and then after that it just exploded One time I had four stories on the stands at the same time, and those two magazines I had to get two new names. So it was an interesting beginning. Okay, excellent. Now you've done a lot of writing for the pulps, but I don't think anybody would categorize you as a pulp writer. Well, you know, this is difficult with the whole matter of categorization anyway. We're in the grip of the taxonomist and people who put labels on things and stick them into cubby holes. Taxonomy has its uses, there's no question about that. You have to be able to find and retrieve information and that's what taxonomy is all about. But more and more, there seems to come over our whole culture the idea that if you can put a label on it, you understand it. And that is not what taxonomy is for. Taxonomy is handles by which you can pick something up and look at it, but for so many people in so many ways, the label is sufficient. You know, he's a Republican, or his mother was a Jew, you know, he's a poet, he's in ESPIT, or whatever. They're all labels, and just so little effort made to understand what's under these labels. Pulp fiction has suffered from the same thing. Pulp actually referred to the kind of paper it was printed on, not to its quality. There was the pulps, and there were the slicks. The slicks were magazines like the Sidered Evening Post and Collier's. And Leady's Home Journal. And pulps were things like Black Mask and Air War Stories and science fiction and fantasy and the like. But it's so easy for the taxonomists and for people who don't pay proper attention to what was going on to feel that pulp was a qualitative comment and slick was also qualitative. Slick paper was better literature than pulp paper. Some of the finest writing around and some of the best pulp writers as such. I mean, the best writers of the time began in pulp and they only gravitated to the slicks not because they got better, but because they got paid more. Ray Bradbury is a perfect example of that. so is Dasha Lennon and the like why do you think that you never became more, I know you've written mainstream fiction, I know you don't like categories either but I wonder why you're mainly noted a lot of your writing is science fiction fantasy rather than mainstream well first of all because I love the field because it's the only genre which has no limitations whatsoever, a lot of people there are the taxonomists who are into it again. They feel that science fiction is the literature of the future and of space. Which is nonsense. It's true that a lot of it is, but you can write science fiction about the past. You can write science fiction about that marvelous place called Other. Just some Other place that doesn't have any reference to where we go in the future. That's the best kind. That's the kind that I think one of the things that science fiction is for. If you don't like the government, go ahead and create a new kind of government give it a push and see how it works uh you can study whole cultures and religions and also some literature and art i've gone into that in some of my stories which are essentially in places that occur just other not in the future or in the past necessarily one of the very finest science fiction books around uh is by somebody i'm very proud to call one of my ex-students. It's called Wild Seed and it's by Octavia Butler. And it begins somewhere around the 17th century and goes up to about 1910, which is hardly future fiction. It's a totally original structure, original idea, and beautifully, beautifully written. That lady is tremendous. She really is one of the big ones. Yeah, I know that book. She is very good. Yeah. Listen, in the late 30s and through the 40s, did you have any contact with those science fiction writers? Was there any sense of community or groupings or anything like that? Oh, sure. I am characteristically not a joiner as such. There was a group called the Hydro Club, which was completely informal. And the rule one was that there are no rules for this organization. And an awful lot of people belong to the Hydro Club. And through that, in the early years, I got to know all sorts of people like Harvigold and Fred Pole and Henry Cutner and so on. Well, the whole raft of those early writers, I think I knew them all. And there was a group there, Fred Pole has written about them called the Futurians. I was never involved in that particularly. early. I attended the very first Milford Science Fiction Writers Conference in Milford, New Jersey. I guess that was in 1951. Judith Merrill I was very close to. I knew virtually everybody in the field at that time, except one or two of the West Coast people. Okay, one sort of general question on your style. Many of your stories have different kinds of style, and I wonder if you experiment deliberately or is it something that comes naturally to you? It's absolutely deliberate. The creation of a style, you can go a long way in the literary business. Steinbeck did it, Aldous Huxley did it. One of the stunning examples is Ray Bradbury. but you develop a style and then you stick to it, pretty soon you become imitable. That is to say anybody with any real facility with words can sit down and write a pure paragraph of Steinbeck or for that matter Hemingway. To imitate Hemingway and Steinbeck is very, very easy and Bradbury particularly is extremely easy to imitate. But you don't imitate Samuel Delaney. for example. You don't imitate, I mean, not by the paragraph. I'm not saying that you can sit down and write a Bradbury story or a Hemingway story. That's a different matter. But we're talking just about the matter of style. And yes, it's a very conscious effort on my part to be able to write with facility in any of a number of styles. And sometimes they're first-person stories. And I write out of the mouth of the person who's talking. And not everybody talks You know, in a high literary style That's what I thought Aldous Huxley For mostly You read an Aldous Huxley novel And Aldous Huxley talks like Aldous Huxley And old men talk like Aldous Huxley And little girls talk like Aldous Huxley It's a Monotone All the words come out of all the mouths With the same kind of cadence And I don't consider This really top writing Why I admire Delaney so much Is that when he talks Ghetto Black, it is for real. But if he has two characters discussing modern American poetry, they talk in terms of William Carlos Williams or T.S. Eliot. And he knows, he's got a good ear, he knows the cadence of this kind of writing. And I admire that so very much. That you can't imitate. And so I consciously do that. Okay, James Gunn has written that because of Sturgeon, other writers have been freer to write what they wish to write and able to find a market for it. I wondered if you were conscious of yourself as having that kind of a role. Not at all. Not at all. I tell you, the last few years have been real revelations to me. For one thing, I didn't realize that I'd had so much personal impact on people until, what was it, six years or so now, Now, I went to Italy, and a woman came up to me dragging an interpreter, and the interpreter said she doesn't speak any English, but there are two things that she wants to tell you. One of them is that you write women better than any writer she knows. And the other thing is that because of something that you wrote, she did not kill herself one night. And the woman began to cry, and the interpreter began to cry, and I began to cry. And it was quite an experience. I suddenly realized that what I have done, apparently, I've been able to reach a great many people far deeper than I had any idea that I was doing. When I look back over the mail that I've gotten over the years, I realize how many people in how many different ways have told me that same kind of thing. It's extremely gratifying. It's also a little frightening. I mean, it's frightening enough to make you terrified of touching your typewriter. what's his name not Lafferty I'm sorry I have to stop a minute and think of it Barry Malzberg wrote a fascinating book called Engines of the Night and I have a quote from it here that somebody's earrocks for me and sent to me and he said the most important science fiction writer of the 40s was probably Theodore Sturgeon He said he was not the best or the most significant, nor did he make the most fundamental impression, even as a stylist, the basis of his reputation. He might have fallen behind a cutness in top form, but what Sturgeon did was to keep open the possibility for a kind of science fiction that eventually many others came to do, which in itself is very gratifying. He says Sturgeon's contribution was unique in his use of style, internalization, and quirky characterization. He was keeping the door open for everything that happened after 1950, when the gold voucher and the 50s perspective became the alternative that dominated the field. If he had not been around through this decade to hold the flag for this kind of science fiction, had not established that the literature could be style-oriented, it is possible that the 50s perspective would not have developed. The editors and potential audience might have been there, but no basis would have been existed upon which writers within the field could build. It's so gratifying to read a thing like that, you know. Years after the fact, Halsburg never told me, I think he was writing that in an essay. And I came on it quite by accident. But apparently that was the case. And I'll tell you quickly a story. A few years ago, there was a little boy who went to see his buddy. He was six or seven years old. His mother told him to be back before dark. And he was so busy playing with his friend that he looked out the window and saw it was dark and he went rushing home and like little kids will he dragged a stick along a picket fence and when he got to the corner he whanged it against the lamppost and immediately all the lights in the northeastern United States went out. Remember that one? That big blackout? He went rushing home to his mother weeping and threw himself into her arms and said, God mommy I didn't mean it. I didn't mean it. Well this is the way I felt when I first read things like this. very gratifying and very surprising to me no, I did not do that on purpose honest to God, mom, I didn't mean it yeah, a lot of critics that I've read feel that same way that's a pretty universal opinion in relation to that a number of critics and authors also identify you as sort of a shatterer of taboos some of the themes that you wrote about just hadn't been handled in science fiction before yeah, that's right, that I've done on purpose Stand by for a coffee. Coughing over. Yes, I have purposely broken taboos. And, you know, I wrote the first stories in science fiction about homosexuality, for example, which dealt with homosexuality and with incest. And I had a three-parter in Omni last year which dealt with cannibalism. But these stories were not about homosexuality. and about incest and about cannibalism. Essentially, they were about confrontation. All my life, I've been infuriated by people who shuck away from an idea. I don't want to hear about that. Oh, don't tell me that. I don't want to hear it. You know, that always angers me. Because only by confrontation can we really learn anything. The whole history of, well, a subject like masturbation, for example, which absolutely terrified the three or four generations before mine, and preoccupied them too. The inventor of one of our more famous breakfast foods, he was a nutritional doctor, and he used to write dietary and medical advice books for the home. And about 75% of them has to do with masturbation and how it will make your hair fall out and give you a softening of the brain and tuberculosis and cancer and all kinds of things. nowadays with a little confrontation and a little research and study, you can read in the highest level of women's magazines not only how to do it but how to do it well and it's become a totally accepted practice but the horror that went on because people would not confront it or would not find out what the truth was caused so much frightful damage I mean, people committed suicide over that. I had a relative whose whole life was absolutely made hell by his preoccupation with that. To be tempted and finally to yield and then feel guilty and feel guilty and so guilty that he would never tell anybody about it. It wrecked his whole life. That was a lot of years ago. I mean, it was in the past generation. but it's an example of what I mean now people have got to confront if we meet you'll probably see me wearing a little silver medallion it's a letter cute with an arrow to it it's my trademark and what it means is ask the next question to me it's the symbol of everything that humanity has ever created and it's the only way it has been created by people asking the next question the one that follows and so often people ask the next question and the one that follows and the one that follows until they suddenly come to a question they don't want to ask because they're afraid they might get the answer and there they stop and when you stop asking the next question you die, you become a zombie and join the ranks of the zombies you see marching around you who have stopped asking the next question it's a very symbol of life and of progress and of science and everything toward basic truth when you ever reach basic truth you'll find not a thing or a precept, but you'll find a process. You'll find something going on. And this is the way I've been thinking apparently all my life. I get very, very irritated when I find that people refuse to think beyond a certain point. There's a bumper sticker that goes around in the Bible Belt. God said it. I believe it. That settled it. When you see a bumper sticker like that, you've just heard the crash of a closing mind. there's plenty of room out there to confront the whole idea of God and to go on with it and ask the next question and the question that follows without committing any particular kind of sin excellent, that's very good I'm in the middle of the Bible Belt out here in Odessa I know exactly what you mean, those kind of people isn't that a great bumper sticker? yeah God said it, I believe it, that settles it yeah, okay listen, let me ask a couple questions about some of your particular works. The book Venus Plus X, which I guess was published in 1960, I suppose the impetus behind that was the sexual stereotyping in our society. Yeah, that's right. That came about when I was leaping through a magazine, and I saw an ad for, of all things, tire chains. Weed tire chains. And there was a photograph of a girl in her underwear holding out a tire chain. And it struck me cold. I said, what? on Earth got to do with a tire chain? Clearly, you know, it was a grabber by the advertising business. Maybe stop and look at the ads. but what has a girl with a clothes dog got to do with a tire chain? And I began to think what kind of a civilization, what would it be like to live in a culture where there was no particular sexual bias at all? And so I started, first of all, creating a society in which there was no sexual at all. That people were regenerated like oysters, which can be both either male or female. But at the beginning there neither. and I couldn't make that work. So I went in another direction and created a race of people and each individual was both sexist. And therefore there was no sexual differentiation. They were just people. And it got into their love, marriage, their sexuality, also into their art, their literature, their architecture. And so I had a ball with that. Venus Plus X is not, you know, really a novel at all. It's a tract. It's an exposition of the ideas that I was getting at the time. Yeah, you wouldn't necessarily advocate the kind of surgical alteration in that book. No, by no means. You have to be careful of that one. An author comes out with a rather radical notion. It's very easy to assume that he's promoting that. Heinlein for example got a lot of rocks thrown at him for a starship trooper because they felt that that was particularly the kind of military he advocates, it's not not really, he has a military background, it's perfectly true which made his description of the starship trooper seem very real and that he was promoting it he also has a reputation for being a male chauvinist pig however I know the man extremely me well and I know that that could be the least of cases. He's the only married man I've ever seen who always rises to his feet when his wife comes into the room In the Notebooks of Lazarus Long there are several items somewhere a page long and some are only a paragraph or a sentence but the very shortest one in the Notebooks of Lazarus Long could not possibly have been written by a male chauvinist pig You know what it is? rub her feet Thank you. Okay. Would you say that More Than Human is probably your best known word? Is that the one you get most responsive? I would say so. And when I sold Finnish and Israeli rites two years ago, it got into its 15th and 16th languages. And just how many editions, I have no idea. Genuinely, I know there were five or six English editions and several Spanish and a number of French and four Japanese editions. And I think I'm proudest of all of that. If a novel can pass the language barrier and the cultural barrier and go into more editions then I think that's a real achievement. The French now have film rights and it's in the works now to be a film finally after all these years. we had a really superb director but through various machinations he has dropped out so I don't know exactly who is going to direct it at this point the script is written by me and by Jane Tannehill my lady Jane my wife who's a superb script writer well she's a very loaded lady she really is tremendous person she is at the moment down at the metaphysical center where She will be ordained a minister in the American Holistic Church next July. She completed all last season with the San Diego Symphony Orchestra and the Master Chorale. She's a chorale singer and a composer and a musician and a born teacher. She's also an established science fiction writer. she's sold analog and amazing and chrysalis and as I say a very very accomplished person and as a script writer she's really splendid it was a joy to work with her and I don't work easily with other people but we wrote a a very fine script for more than human and I suspect there'll be more coming up of that of our collaborating on screenplay that's good that's good I'm happy to hear that about the movie of course I guess that was The original story there was in Baby Makes Three. I wonder why it made you... Baby Makes Three. Yeah. Yeah. What made you add the other two to that? The springboard for that was in a book by Pearl Buck, which was called Pavilion of Women. I read it so many years ago that I hardly remember the book at all. But there was one passage in there which described a monk who took care of some children in a cave in the woods, and they were uneducated and wild children. They'd have died without him. And he was just an impoverished monk himself, and he took care of these raggedy little children. And that image always stayed with me. And somehow that and the whole idea of what would happen if each of these children, coming from various places and being various kinds of children, had very special ESP talents. and again it was a question of investigating what the impact would be on the world as a whole as some of the newly recognized proclivities of the human mind came up and this of course there are literally thousands of books that have been written on that theme since then of course the people in that book as in so many of your other stories and novels I think they're sort of misfits and I wondered why you pick that kind of character so often. Well, I think a misfit has a chance to be objective. And for one thing, he sees society as a whole from its underbelly or from way off at one side. Essentially, it's not so much misfits. The key to what I write, I think, is loneliness. I learned earlier that you can write about excitement, you can write about adventure, you can write love and sex. so on. And basically, in each case, you don't hit too many people. But if you write about loneliness, everybody's an expert. I'm fond of saying that if you know some guy who collects pheasant feathers, and that's his whole preoccupation, and you write a story that involves pheasant feathers, and you know what you're talking about, he's going to love it. But the incidence of people in the general population who collect pheasant feathers is very small. but the point is that because you wrote to an expert of an expertise you see you grab him now what are people as a whole mostly expert at loneliness the world is full of experts on loneliness it's something that everybody recognizes when he sees it so it's not so much that these people are misfits it's that they're lonely and I think that that's the hook that I can throw into people the hardest but then on the other hand a number of your stories too give the solution to that is some sort of love that's right I would have said that love is probably the principal theme I find through all your work that's right and isn't it the antithesis of loneliness I mean it's the yin and the yang it's the balancing principle to loneliness and the cure for loneliness is love individual to individual or individual in his relationship to the entire world. Yeah, I would have said love in all its meanings, not necessarily individuals, but in all of its... That's right. Okay. One more brief question on that More Than Human book. Do you think that we do have latent ESP or psi powers? There's no question about it. I've always felt so. And particularly so in the seven years I've been married to Jane because Jane is a psychic and she's now involved in the metaphysical center here in San Diego and she's learning and teaching both these whole courses on all sorts of metaphysical subjects further than that I recently attended a fascinating seminar at the Esplan Institute up on the coast there oh lord what a beautiful place that is the seminar was run by Dr. Lilly, John Lilly. You've heard of him in connection with dolphins and the like. And Amit Goswami, who's a theoretical physicist from the University of Oregon. And Arthur Young, he's the man who invented the helicopter and so on. And the general thrust of the thing was quantum mechanics. And when quantum mechanics gets up into its higher levels, it approaches philosophy, metaphysics, and religion. there's no question about it but it also deals with the potentialities of the human mind and is ESP and so on and we ran some experiments during that seminar on precognition and telepathy and so on with rather breathtaking results you'll find quantum mechanics people generally if you go into the book section which has to do with philosophy and quantum mechanics, you'll find this melding coming along between these higher levels of science and philosophy. And it always includes something about the untapped possibilities of the human mind. This ceases to be totally fantastic anymore. The psychic possibilities, so-called supernatural, is one of the better documented things. There are documents going back 2,000 years which deal with it. And we've all experienced it. Sometimes we don't notice our own experiences, but we do. And investigations of such things as past lives and so on, it's just fascinating to get into. You don't have to believe everything about it. You can take a perfectly scientific attitude and simply sit around gathering data. The thing is, you could gather the data you don't like as well as the data that you do like. There's a paradigm there with flying saucers, excuse me, where people ask questions of me at conventions. Do you believe in flying saucers? Well, do I believe in unidentified flying objects? Yeah. And anybody with any observation has seen flying objects which we couldn't identify. do I believe they come from a certain planet or that they have people in there who've come to Earth to straighten us out for our old problems because we can't sell them ourselves and so on? No, I don't believe that. I would sit and gather data until I got hardware and bodies until I can really know precisamente and exactly what these things are. So I make no assumptions. I just gather data. But if something comes along which I prefer not to believe, if it's hard data, I'll believe it. I won't believe it until it is hard data, however. But you've got to keep your mind open for any facts that come in or listen to anything that anybody says and just hold it in abeyance until it's either proved or disproved. There's no sense in screaming about chariots from heaven and then screaming just as hard is that there are no chariots from heaven. Just gather data quietly until... If you gather enough data about anything, you'll find out what the truth is. The only great crime in that area is to get data and then not tell anybody that you have it and the military is extremely guilty of that. Right, okay. I guess I would probably characterize you this is sort of another way of saying what we were just talking about as a romantic and I would point to say a story like Thunder and Roses as an example of that. Yeah, that's a very interesting story. That was written, you know, when the dust was still settling over Hiroshima. It's probably the first atomic doom story that was written after the bomb was dropped. It was written in late 1945. And I wrote that with considerable passion. There wasn't anybody in the world who understood what had happened, except the people in the science fiction fraternity, and maybe one or two rather forward-thinking scientists at Oak Ridge and in the state of Washington. and for the rest of the world thought it was just another Big Bang. But in science fiction there, John Campbell had been publishing Atomic Power and Atomic War stories for 15 years before that. And we all understood what had happened. Every single person who had been writing or reading science fiction understood precisely what had happened and what it meant to the world. Now, of course, it's become very much in the forefront, but we all saw it coming. Very bad. An ugly situation. Yeah, that was a powerful story. I guess you get a lot of response about that one, don't you? Oh, yes, I do. And it's been reprinted a good many times. As a matter of fact, Ben Bubba was just about to publish it in Omni as a classic when he left. And I don't know what the situation is with the story again, but chances are it will show up there. Yeah, and in relation to that, too, you've written about a number of discoveries or events before they ever came about. Has that ever been pointed out to you? Time and again. Last year, a long section from one of my stories was the heading of an article in the Institute for Electronic and Electrical Engineers in their journal, and it had to do with the creation of a duplicated random. That is, that you have a random sequence, and you duplicate that random elsewhere, which is a direct conquits direction in terms. But this happens to be just the core of a new development in satellite communications, particularly military satellite communications, which can't be tapped. You can't tap a random communication unless, of course, you can know what that randomness is in which case it's not random anymore. But it's a duplicated random, and essentially that's what's been developed. that was, oh, 20 years before it had been accomplished. I had been accused of inventing Velcro, which is in one of my stories about 15 years before it appeared on the market. The illuminated wristwatch with a readout was in one of my stories. The most amazing thing of all, though, was before Watson then quickly discovered the DNA, the structure of the DNA molecule, I had a story about some people who were marooned on a planet and when they came out of their, they had all been frozen when they came out of their little frozen cocoons they found that they were on a planet that was not on any of their star charts and standing in the cabin with them was a religious symbol of a double spiral and the whole story had to do with evolution First recidivism, each generation of these maroon people was slightly more primitive than the one before. It got right down to the cell. And then that cell began to revolve again into something else. And the whole figure, the whole symbolism there was of a double spiral, a double helix. And, you know, something that goes down to a base and continues to spiral back up again into something else. And lo and behold, years later, And Rick and Watson discovered the structure of the DNA molecule which contains all this information. Now, where that kind of thing comes from, I just can't begin to tell you. But it has happened to me time and time and time again. That story you're referring to was the golden helix, wasn't it? Yeah. Yeah, I was thinking also about, I guess it was one of your very first science fiction stories, the ether breather in 1939, where you get a picture of the importance, the public importance, the impact of television. I didn't even know there was television then. Yeah, it became widely public around 1948, and I had already been writing for 10 years, and I started writing as a very, very much of a youngster. Do you recall how you assumed television was going to be so important or how that story came out? Well, I was living in New York at that time, along around Rockefeller Center, and there was a whole lot in the radio and in the newspapers about television the first television uh broadcast was done in 1925 by some scientists at cbs and they used the scanning disc with a bunch of little holes on a spinning disc and the light scanned up and down the holes were drilled in a very close spiral and the light scanned back and forth as it spun put little spots of light on the screen and there was quite a battle between that system and the cathode ray tube. And this cathode ray tube finally won out. You'd have to have a spinning disc in your set, too, in the home and they'd have to be synchronized with what was being broadcast, which was the chief difficulty with it. But there's an interesting thing that in that story, I learned a great deal of everything I could possibly find out about television at the time. And I realized the enormous difficulties. Black and white television was one thing, but color television was something else again. was such a hard nut to crack and so complex a technological achievement that I put it 200 years ahead in the future. And it turned out the first colored sets came out about three years later. So often a science fiction writer is way ahead of science but there are times when science jumps way ahead of the science fiction writer. The microprocessor, for example, was hardly mentioned in any story ever until it suddenly appeared on people's wrists. I mean, that's one time when technology really got the jump on us. I could kick myself for that, too, because way back in the early 40s, I met a guy who told me about a German patent which had run out and was now a public domain of a liquid crystal in which, if you pass the vultures through it, the transparent drift crystal became opaque. He told me about that as a kind of laboratory phenomenon. I could have taken that and run with it, but I didn't. And that's the secret of your liquid crystal watch. Okay, one of my favorite stories that you've written. I don't think it's one of your more characteristic ones, but it's one of your better knowns. It's the microcosmic God. Yeah, I'm not too fond of that story. Not because the idea isn't unique. It is. It was a brand new kind of an idea. But because it was so badly written. It was the first science fiction story I wrote. And there was so much that I did not know about writing. And one of the most important things about people as a whole, and if you're going to write people well, is that nobody's all bad. Nobody's all good either. But the heavy in there was the bank president, that he's cut out of 100% pure cardboard. He is so poorly written. And that angers me every time I think of it. If I were to write it today, he would be very dimensional, and there would be some good things about him too. And then you could believe him. the idea itself the little people under the dome was so overwhelming that nobody else but me apparently noticed how badly that story is read well the idea carries it so well that you know the characterization just isn't noticed I don't think that's right it's called the dazzle principle you can write with something really bright enough people don't notice the flaws but I do okay listen what about your horror fiction do you like to write horror stories Sometimes, yes. It's nice to give a, that they have an amazing impact on people sometimes. Although nowadays I think they're being vastly overdone. And white people are flocking to see all these imitations of the exorcist and so on. I don't know. It's depressing. It really is. And each one you see, of course, has less impact than the one before. And it's got to be more bloody and more gory and more horrible and more flesh brains and buckets of gore and so on. So it loses its impact. You've got overdoses of that stuff. But there's a certain something in the titillation of horror. I wrote one story. It was called Professor Teddy Bear. Years later, I went to a convention and a lady came up to me and she was all claws. She was only caught my eyes out. She was so furious for having written that story. It seemed that when she read it, Didn't get any sleep for two weeks. And in some peculiar way, she blamed me for it, that is, as if I had personally written it personally to upset her. However, that kind of reaction is very rare. Mostly people kind of enjoy it because basically they know they're safe in spite of the fact that you have been living in terror for a little while. Yeah, that was, I remember that story, but the one that impressed me the most is a very understated horror story, and that would be Bianca's hands. Oh yeah. Now that has really struck down deep to some people, and I couldn't find out why. I think it's the understatement of it. It's so subtly done, and when you think about it, it just becomes more horrible all the time. Well, for one thing, it's a love story. It's very profoundly a love story. and people don't like to associate love with the things that happen in that story and yet there's what they call the lebestote, the love death and essentially this kind of consummation I think is something that on a very deep level that people do recognize that death and love have a great deal in common. The image of Kali, you know, the goddess, the Hindu goddess with all the arms, Kali is the goddess of death but she's also the source they're one and the same thing and the idea of the Leasteau the love death being worked by all kinds of people from Richard Wagner right on through that love and death are the same thing that the ending is also the beginning and people gravitate to that but it's down so deep that when they really begin to get a glimpse of it. They're terrified. One lady read the story once and horrified her just terribly. She happened to be a rabid sturgeon fan and I met her at a convention and I recorded that story for Cadman Records and it was for alternate world records which is now in the possession of Cadman and she definitely wanted to buy the record and get my autograph on it but on the other hand she couldn't bear the story. And for once I had somebody who'd been that profoundly affected. And I had a chance to kind of pin her wings to the wall and find out why. And she said, well, you know why. I said, no, I don't, really I don't. Tell me why it upset you. And she said, all those disembodied hands crawling all around over the house.

segments.text: I'm sure you've been asked before,
and I probably know the answers to them myself,
but maybe a lot of the listeners in the radio show won't.
So, you know, just put up with that, I guess.
Oh, sure, yeah. I'm well used to that.
Yeah, I'm sure.
Tell me your front name again.
Darryl.
Darryl.
Yeah, Darryl.
Okay.
I'm an English teacher here at Odessa College.
Right.
Okay, listen, you obviously had an extremely varied background,
and I wondered if you could just say a few words about how you began as a writer.
Okay.
I began to write when I was an able seaman in the Merchant Marine,
and how that came about was that I left home before I graduated from high school.
It's a fascinating thing.
I lecture at colleges and universities all over the United States
and in England and in France,
And I have yet to get my high school diploma.
Someday somebody will grant me an honorary high school diploma.
But anyway, I was on the ship.
And you had a lot of time to read.
And I conceived the idea of an absolutely foolproof crime
that would net me thousands and thousands of dollars.
And I even did research on it.
I was on a coastwise tanker.
And as I was going up and down the coast,
when we stopped at a port,
I would send off a letter to the railroad,
so it was one of the things that was involved,
and the insurance companies, that was another,
and the post office, that was still another.
I got all my research done
as to how to commit this particular kind of robbery,
and they had letters carefully written
so that nobody would know what I was up to.
And when I had all my material,
I found that I did not have the immoral courage
to commit the crime,
so I wrote it as a story.
this was way back in the late 30s and i sent my story off to a newspaper syndicate i didn't know
anything about writing particularly and there was they were buying a 1500 word short short stories
that they published every day in the in the syndicate and uh when i got up to new york in
the ship to my amazement i got a letter of acceptance and uh so i quit the sea and
and came ashore to be a writer.
And I got my money, not on acceptance, but on publication.
And it was five whole dollars.
And they would buy one and sometimes two stories a week, but no more.
And so four and a half months or so,
I lived on five and sometimes ten dollars a week.
My room cost me seven.
And whatever I saved, I could eat.
And I learned a lot about being hungry.
Did you ever notice that pound cake has no crust on the ends?
What they do is chop them off and they sell them in their day-old store.
And at that time, you could get a whole shopping bag full of cake ends for a nickel.
And so I used to live on that.
One time, I got a whole shopping bag full and it was moldy, but I ate it anyhow.
And I was so sick, I didn't eat for three days, and so I saved myself some money.
You know, like that.
It was a hard school.
it really was
but
then I
finally after
some months of that
and I think I went back to C for a short while
I finally met
John Campbell
early 1939
he was the editor of Astounding Science Fiction
and a wonderful fantasy magazine
called Unknown
and
so I started writing for him
and then after that it just exploded
One time I had four stories on the stands at the same time,
and those two magazines I had to get two new names.
So it was an interesting beginning.
Okay, excellent.
Now you've done a lot of writing for the pulps,
but I don't think anybody would categorize you as a pulp writer.
Well, you know, this is difficult with the whole matter of categorization anyway.
We're in the grip of the taxonomist
and people who put labels on things
and stick them into cubby holes.
Taxonomy has its uses,
there's no question about that.
You have to be able to find and retrieve information
and that's what taxonomy is all about.
But more and more,
there seems to come over our whole culture
the idea that if you can put a label on it,
you understand it.
And that is not what taxonomy is for.
Taxonomy is handles by which you can pick something up and look at it,
but for so many people in so many ways, the label is sufficient.
You know, he's a Republican, or his mother was a Jew,
you know, he's a poet, he's in ESPIT, or whatever.
They're all labels, and just so little effort made to understand what's under these labels.
Pulp fiction has suffered from the same thing.
Pulp actually referred to the kind of paper it was printed on, not to its quality.
There was the pulps, and there were the slicks.
The slicks were magazines like the Sidered Evening Post and Collier's.
And Leady's Home Journal.
And pulps were things like Black Mask and Air War Stories and science fiction and fantasy and the like.
But it's so easy for the taxonomists and for people who don't pay proper attention to what was going on
to feel that pulp was a qualitative comment
and slick was also qualitative.
Slick paper was better literature than pulp paper.
Some of the finest writing around
and some of the best pulp writers as such.
I mean, the best writers of the time began in pulp
and they only gravitated to the slicks
not because they got better,
but because they got paid more.
Ray Bradbury is a perfect example of that.
so is Dasha Lennon
and the like
why do you
think that you never
became more, I know you've written
mainstream fiction, I know you don't like categories
either but I wonder why you're
mainly noted a lot of your writing is science fiction
fantasy rather than mainstream
well first of all because I love the field
because it's the only
genre which has no limitations
whatsoever, a lot of
people there are the taxonomists who are into it again. They feel that science fiction is the
literature of the future and of space. Which is nonsense. It's true that a lot of it is, but
you can write science fiction about the past. You can write science fiction about that
marvelous place called Other. Just some Other place that doesn't have any reference to where
we go in the future. That's the best kind. That's the kind that I think one of the things
that science fiction is for. If you don't like the government, go ahead and create a
new kind of government give it a push and see how it works uh you can study whole cultures and
religions and also some literature and art i've gone into that in some of my stories
which are essentially in places that occur just other not in the future or in the past necessarily
one of the very finest science fiction books around uh is by somebody i'm very proud to call
one of my ex-students.
It's called Wild Seed
and it's by Octavia Butler.
And it begins somewhere
around the 17th century
and goes up to about 1910,
which is hardly future fiction.
It's a totally original structure,
original idea,
and beautifully,
beautifully written.
That lady is tremendous.
She really is
one of the big ones.
Yeah, I know that book.
She is very good.
Yeah.
Listen, in the late 30s and through the 40s, did you have any contact with those science fiction writers?
Was there any sense of community or groupings or anything like that?
Oh, sure. I am characteristically not a joiner as such.
There was a group called the Hydro Club, which was completely informal.
And the rule one was that there are no rules for this organization.
And an awful lot of people belong to the Hydro Club.
And through that, in the early years, I got to know all sorts of people like Harvigold and Fred Pole and Henry Cutner and so on.
Well, the whole raft of those early writers, I think I knew them all.
And there was a group there, Fred Pole has written about them called the Futurians.
I was never involved in that particularly.
early. I attended the very first Milford Science Fiction Writers Conference in Milford, New
Jersey. I guess that was in 1951. Judith Merrill I was very close to. I knew virtually everybody
in the field at that time, except one or two of the West Coast people.
Okay, one sort of general question on your style.
Many of your stories have different kinds of style,
and I wonder if you experiment deliberately
or is it something that comes naturally to you?
It's absolutely deliberate.
The creation of a style,
you can go a long way in the literary business.
Steinbeck did it, Aldous Huxley did it.
One of the stunning examples is Ray Bradbury.
but you develop a style and then you stick to it,
pretty soon you become imitable.
That is to say anybody with any real facility with words
can sit down and write a pure paragraph of Steinbeck
or for that matter Hemingway.
To imitate Hemingway and Steinbeck is very, very easy
and Bradbury particularly is extremely easy to imitate.
But you don't imitate Samuel Delaney.
for example.
You don't imitate,
I mean, not by the paragraph.
I'm not saying that you can sit down
and write a Bradbury story
or a Hemingway story.
That's a different matter.
But we're talking just about
the matter of style.
And yes,
it's a very conscious effort
on my part
to be able to write with facility
in any of a number of styles.
And sometimes
they're first-person stories.
And I write out of the mouth
of the person who's talking.
And not everybody talks
You know, in a high literary style
That's what I thought Aldous Huxley
For mostly
You read an Aldous Huxley novel
And Aldous Huxley talks like Aldous Huxley
And old men talk like Aldous Huxley
And little girls talk like Aldous Huxley
It's a
Monotone
All the words come out of all the mouths
With the same kind of cadence
And I don't consider
This really top writing
Why I admire Delaney so much
Is that when he talks
Ghetto Black, it is for real.
But if he has two characters
discussing modern American poetry,
they talk in terms of
William Carlos Williams
or T.S. Eliot.
And he knows,
he's got a good ear, he knows the cadence
of this kind of writing.
And I admire that so very much.
That you can't imitate.
And so I
consciously do that.
Okay,
James Gunn has written that because of Sturgeon, other writers have been freer to write what they wish to write and able to find a market for it.
I wondered if you were conscious of yourself as having that kind of a role.
Not at all. Not at all.
I tell you, the last few years have been real revelations to me.
For one thing, I didn't realize that I'd had so much personal impact on people until, what was it, six years or so now,
Now, I went to Italy, and a woman came up to me dragging an interpreter,
and the interpreter said she doesn't speak any English,
but there are two things that she wants to tell you.
One of them is that you write women better than any writer she knows.
And the other thing is that because of something that you wrote,
she did not kill herself one night.
And the woman began to cry, and the interpreter began to cry,
and I began to cry.
And it was quite an experience.
I suddenly realized that what I have done, apparently,
I've been able to reach a great many people
far deeper than I had any idea that I was doing.
When I look back over the mail that I've gotten over the years,
I realize how many people in how many different ways
have told me that same kind of thing.
It's extremely gratifying.
It's also a little frightening.
I mean, it's frightening enough to make you
terrified of touching your typewriter.
what's his name
not Lafferty
I'm sorry I have to
stop a minute and think of it
Barry Malzberg
wrote a fascinating book
called Engines of the Night
and I have a quote from it here
that somebody's earrocks
for me and sent to me
and he said
the most important
science fiction writer
of the 40s
was probably
Theodore Sturgeon
He said he was not the best

nor did he make the most fundamental impression,
even as a stylist,
the basis of his reputation.
He might have fallen behind
a cutness in top form,
but what Sturgeon did
was to keep open the possibility
for a kind of science fiction
that eventually many others came to do,
which in itself is very gratifying.
He says Sturgeon's contribution was unique
in his use of style,
internalization,
and quirky characterization.
He was keeping the door open
for everything that happened after 1950,
when the gold voucher and the 50s perspective
became the alternative that dominated the field.
If he had not been around through this decade
to hold the flag for this kind of science fiction,
had not established that the literature
could be style-oriented,
it is possible that the 50s perspective
would not have developed.
The editors and potential audience
might have been there,
but no basis would have been existed upon
which writers within the field could build.
It's so gratifying to read a thing like that, you know.
Years after the fact,
Halsburg never told me,
I think he was writing that in an essay.
And I came on it quite by accident.
But apparently that was the case.
And I'll tell you quickly a story.
A few years ago,
there was a little boy who went to see his buddy.
He was six or seven years old.
His mother told him to be back before dark.
And he was so busy playing with his friend
that he looked out the window and saw it was dark
and he went rushing home
and like little kids will
he dragged a stick along a picket fence
and when he got to the corner
he whanged it against the lamppost
and immediately all the lights
in the northeastern United States
went out.
Remember that one?
That big blackout?
He went rushing home to his mother
weeping and threw himself into her arms
and said,
God mommy I didn't mean it.
I didn't mean it.
Well this is the way I felt
when I first read things like this.
very gratifying and very surprising to me
no, I did not do that on purpose
honest to God, mom, I didn't mean it
yeah, a lot of critics that I've read feel that same way
that's a pretty universal opinion
in relation to that
a number of critics and authors also
identify you as sort of a shatterer of taboos
some of the themes that you wrote about
just hadn't been handled in science fiction before
yeah, that's right, that I've done on purpose
Stand by for a coffee.
Coughing over.
Yes, I have purposely broken taboos.
And, you know, I wrote the first stories in science fiction about homosexuality, for example,
which dealt with homosexuality and with incest.
And I had a three-parter in Omni last year which dealt with cannibalism.
But these stories were not about homosexuality.
and about incest and about cannibalism.
Essentially, they were about confrontation.
All my life, I've been infuriated by people
who shuck away from an idea.
I don't want to hear about that.
Oh, don't tell me that.
I don't want to hear it.
You know, that always angers me.
Because only by confrontation can we really learn anything.
The whole history of, well, a subject like masturbation,
for example, which absolutely terrified
the three or four generations before mine,
and preoccupied them too.
The inventor of one of our more famous breakfast foods,
he was a nutritional doctor,
and he used to write dietary and medical advice books for the home.
And about 75% of them has to do with masturbation
and how it will make your hair fall out
and give you a softening of the brain and tuberculosis
and cancer and all kinds of things.
nowadays with a little
confrontation and a little research
and study, you can read
in
the highest level of women's
magazines not only how to do
it but how to do it well
and
it's become a totally accepted
practice
but the horror that went on because
people would not confront it or would not find out
what the truth was
caused so much frightful damage
I mean, people committed suicide over that.
I had a relative whose whole life was absolutely made hell by his preoccupation with that.
To be tempted and finally to yield and then feel guilty and feel guilty
and so guilty that he would never tell anybody about it.
It wrecked his whole life.
That was a lot of years ago.
I mean, it was in the past generation.
but it's an example
of what I mean
now people have got
to confront
if we meet
you'll probably see me
wearing a little
silver medallion
it's a letter cute
with an arrow
to it
it's my trademark
and what it means
is ask the next question
to me
it's the symbol
of everything
that humanity
has ever created
and it's the only way
it has been created
by people asking
the next question
the one that follows
and so often
people ask the next question

they don't want to ask because they're afraid
they might get the answer
and there they stop
and when you stop asking the next question
you die, you become a zombie
and join the ranks of the zombies you see
marching around you
who have stopped asking the next question
it's a very symbol of life and of progress
and of science and
everything toward basic truth
when you ever reach basic truth
you'll find
not a thing or a precept,
but you'll find a process.
You'll find something going on.
And this is the way
I've been thinking apparently
all my life.
I get very, very irritated
when I find that people
refuse to think
beyond a certain point.
There's a bumper sticker
that goes around
in the Bible Belt.
God said it.
I believe it.
That settled it.
When you see a bumper sticker
like that,
you've just heard the crash
of a closing mind.
there's plenty of room out there to confront the whole idea of God
and to go on with it
and ask the next question and the question that follows
without committing any particular kind of sin
excellent, that's very good
I'm in the middle of the Bible Belt out here in Odessa
I know exactly what you mean, those kind of people
isn't that a great bumper sticker?
yeah

yeah, okay
listen, let me ask a couple questions
about some of your particular works.
The book Venus Plus X,
which I guess was published in 1960,
I suppose the impetus behind that
was the sexual stereotyping in our society.
Yeah, that's right.
That came about when I was leaping through a magazine,
and I saw an ad for, of all things, tire chains.
Weed tire chains.
And there was a photograph of a girl
in her underwear holding out a tire chain.
And it struck me cold.
I said, what?
on Earth got to do with a tire chain?
Clearly, you know,
it was a grabber by the advertising business.
Maybe stop and look at the ads.
but what has a girl with a clothes dog got to do with a tire chain?
And I began to think what kind of a civilization,
what would it be like to live in a culture
where there was no particular sexual bias at all?
And so I started, first of all,
creating a society in which there was no sexual at all.
That people were regenerated like oysters,
which can be both either male or female.
But at the beginning there neither.
and I couldn't make that work.
So I went in another direction
and created a race of people
and each individual was both sexist.
And therefore there was no sexual differentiation.
They were just people.
And it got into their love, marriage,
their sexuality,
also into their art, their literature,
their architecture.
And so I had a ball with that.
Venus Plus X is not, you know, really a novel at all.
It's a tract.
It's an exposition of the ideas that I was getting at the time.
Yeah, you wouldn't necessarily advocate the kind of surgical alteration in that book.
No, by no means.
You have to be careful of that one.
An author comes out with a rather radical notion.
It's very easy to assume that he's promoting that.
Heinlein for example got a lot of rocks
thrown at him for a starship
trooper because they felt
that that was particularly the kind of military
he advocates, it's not
not really, he has a military

he also has a reputation for

however I know the man extremely

there are several items

You know what it is?
rub her feet

Would you say that More Than Human is probably your best known word?
Is that the one you get most responsive?
I would say so.
And when I sold Finnish and Israeli rites two years ago,
it got into its 15th and 16th languages.
And just how many editions, I have no idea.
Genuinely, I know there were five or six English editions
and several Spanish
and a number of French
and four Japanese editions.
And I think I'm proudest of all of that.
If a novel can pass the language barrier
and the cultural barrier
and go into more editions
then I think that's a real achievement.
The French now have film rights
and it's in the works now to be a film
finally after all these years.
we had a really superb director but through various machinations he has dropped out so I

she's sold analog

and

it was a joy to work with her

a very fine script

and I suspect
there'll be more coming up
of that
of our collaborating

that's good
that's good
I'm happy to hear that
about the movie
of course
I guess that was
The original story there was in Baby Makes Three.

Baby Makes Three.
Yeah.
Yeah.
What made you add the other two to that?
The springboard for that was in a book by Pearl Buck,
which was called Pavilion of Women.
I read it so many years ago that I hardly remember the book at all.
But there was one passage in there which described a monk
who took care of some children in a cave in the woods,
and they were uneducated and wild children.
They'd have died without him.
And he was just an impoverished monk himself, and he took care of these raggedy little children.
And that image always stayed with me.
And somehow that and the whole idea of what would happen if each of these children,
coming from various places and being various kinds of children, had very special ESP talents.
and again
it was a question
of investigating
what the impact
would be
on the world
as a whole
as some of
the newly
recognized
proclivities
of the human
mind came up
and this of course
there are literally
thousands of books
that have been
written on that
theme since then
of course
the people
in that book
as in so many
of your other
stories and novels
I think
they're sort of
misfits
and I wondered why you pick that kind of character so often.
Well, I think a misfit has a chance to be objective.
And for one thing, he sees society as a whole from its underbelly
or from way off at one side.
Essentially, it's not so much misfits.
The key to what I write, I think, is loneliness.
I learned earlier that you can write about excitement,
you can write about adventure, you can write love and sex.
so on.
And basically, in each case, you don't hit too many people.
But if you write about loneliness, everybody's an expert.
I'm fond of saying that if you know some guy who collects pheasant feathers, and that's
his whole preoccupation, and you write a story that involves pheasant feathers, and you know
what you're talking about, he's going to love it.
But the incidence of people in the general population who collect pheasant feathers is
very small.
but the point is that
because you wrote
to an expert
of an expertise
you see you grab him
now what are people
as a whole
mostly expert at
loneliness
the world is full of
experts on loneliness
it's something that
everybody recognizes
when he sees it
so
it's not so much
that these people
are misfits
it's that they're lonely
and I think
that that's the hook
that I can throw
into people the hardest
but then on the other hand
a number of your stories too
give the solution to that
is some sort of love
that's right
I would have said that love
is probably the principal theme
I find through all your work
that's right
and isn't it the antithesis of loneliness
I mean it's the yin and the yang
it's the balancing principle to loneliness
and the cure for loneliness is love
individual to individual

That's right.

I've always felt so.

further than that
